claims_to_validate.claim_text: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate gratuity amount. When calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity, the system fails to recognize 2024 as a leap year, causing a calculation discrepancy of approximately AED 17.26.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

The daily wage calculator's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The system uses different calculation approaches for complete and incomplete years, including specific handling for leap years by using 366 as a divisor when appropriate.
System may not consistently account for February 29th when calculating service duration for gratuity, potentially causing minor discrepancies in total days worked (912 vs 913 days)

Platform calculates days worked with a potential extra day (622 vs 623 days), causing slight variations in gratuity calculation. The system uses a fixed divisor of 30 days for daily wage, which may not align with all client calculation preferences.

System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days. The daily wage is divided by a configured number of days (30 vs 31), potentially causing salary calculation differences.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using different daily wage divisors (30 vs 30.42 days), causing calculation discrepancies. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to different prorated amounts.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When an employee is offboarded (e.g., on Nov 28th) and payroll is processed earlier (e.g., Nov 27th), the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes inconsistent between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect salary deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.

The platform currently displays incorrect remarks for daily wage calculations in February, showing 31 days instead of the actual 29 days for leap years. While the backend calculation remains accurate, the frontend display creates potential user confusion.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave calculations. This means the daily wage is calculated using a system-wide setting instead of policy-specific methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave occurred.

The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.
